IRS990.ActivityOrMissionDesc: The mission of the College of Saint Benedict is to provide for women the best residential liberal arts education in the Catholic university tradition. The college fosters integrated learning, exceptional leadership for change and wisdom for a lifetime.
IRS990.MissionDesc: The mission of the College of Saint Benedict is to provide for women the best residential liberal arts education in the Catholic university tradition. The College fosters integrated learning, exceptional leadership for change and wisdom for a lifetime.
IRS990.Desc: Higher Education: Educational instruction, 2,035 Fall FTE students enrolled in undergraduate courses, 494 graduates. The College of Saint Benedict designs programs to meet the needs and aspirations of young women, emphasizing women's leadership and a personal development profile that includes intellectual, spiritual, emotional and physical development. Its values-based and value-added residential liberal arts education provides the framework for fulfilling lives of disciplined inquiry and leadership in careers devoted to the professions, public life and service to others.

ProgSrvcAccomActy2Grp.Desc: Higher Education: Auxiliary Revenue (dining, housing, etc.) 2,035 students. The Residential Life program at the College of Saint Benedict provides a four year residential experience of community living which supports and challenges our students with opportunities for personal and social growth. This experience allows women to develop an understanding and appreciation of their responsibilities to themselves and others living in the community on campus and beyond. As the residence hall students' primary dining location, the CSB Gorecki is the "kitchen" of the CSB campus community. As in most American homes today, the kitchen is the heart of a home where family congregate and discuss important issues of the day. We encourage our students to dine, relax, and gather with friends at the CSB Gorecki Center thus promoting a feeling of campus community. Dining at the CSB Gorecki Center provides students with the best value for their food dollars.

ProgSrvcAccomActy3Grp.Desc: Other program services (Fine Arts Programming, etc.). These areas curate a series of arts events that bring the finest regional and national artists to our community; support and enhance the academic mission of CSB through programming, resources, and personnel; create institutional visibility and recognition through active leadership in local, state, and national arts organizations; provide responsible fiscal management of resources and generate revenue through grants, sponsorships, and ticket sales; create learning initiatives to encourage participation in the arts by "students" of all ages; strengthen community resources in the arts through professional support of regional arts organizations that produce and present in our Fine Arts facilities and provide professional development opportunities for educators to promote interdisciplinary teaching through the arts. Expenses related to these revenues are included in Part IX, Statement of Functional Expenses.

SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: This amount represents membership dues to Minnesota Private College Council paid in fiscal year '14 and estimated for lobbying purposes. This represents 0.10% of the College's annual operating expenses relating to the exempt status.

OtherSecuritiesGrp.Desc: Beneficial interest in fund held for others

SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: Endowment draw is used to fund student scholarships and academic programs

The College follows the accounting standards for contingencies in evaluating uncertain tax positions. This guidance prescribes recognition threshold principles for the financial statement recognition of tax positions taken or expected to be taken on a tax return that are not certain to be realized. No liability has been recognized by the College for uncertain tax positions as of June 30, 2014 and 2013. The College's tax returns are subject to review and examination by federal and state authorities. The tax returns for the current year as well as fiscal years 2011 through 2013 are open to examination by federal and state authorities.
Adjustment of actuarial liability on annuities in the amount of -$278,558 and student financial aid in the amount of $36,923,279.

SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The number in column (b) represents the total number of contributions of this type. It does not represent the number of stock shares received.
Stock brokers process the stock transactions when the gift is received and the college chooses to liquidate the stock.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section A, Line 7a
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: As stated in the Articles of Incorporation, the Corporate Members retain the following reserved powers 1)appoint those persons who serve as voting members of the Board of Trustees

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section A, Line 7b
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: As stated in the Articles of Incorporation, the Corporate Members retain the following reserved powers 1)appoint those persons who serve as voting members of the Board of Trustees; 2)approve any merger, acquisition, or dissolution of the Corporation; 3)approve the sale or encumbrance of all or substantially all of the assets of the Corporation;4)amend the Articles of Incorporation, or 5)make and amend the Bylaws of the Corporation. The Corporate Members are the Sisters of the Order of St. Benedict.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, Line 11b
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The subcommittee of the Board of Trustees known as the Audit Committee reviews the 990 during the spring meeting prior to filing the form and the form is made available for review by all board members prior to filing.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, Line 12c
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The Audit Committee reviews all disclosures on the Conflict of Interest policy annually

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, Line 15
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: In accordance with the employee handbook, the compensation plan is designed to ensure positions are competitively valued relative to comparable jobs in the market. The Human Resources department does a comparison of job descriptions to position descriptions in the marketplace annually. The comparison for administrative and support staff positions are approved by the President or Board of Trustees and a salary range is created based on this comparison. The President's salary is reviewed and determined by the Board of Trustees. The positions are compared to similar institutions of higher education with respect to enrollment, budget, and Carnegie classification found in the College and University Personnel Association salary survey.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section C, Line 19
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: Governing documents and conflict of interest policy are not available to the public, but would be made available upon request. The financial statements are available on the website.
Adjustment of actuarial liability on annuities in the amount of $278,559.
